fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let M be a \Sigma -structure in a category \mathcal {C} and \sigma = \Gamma |\varphi \vdash \psi be a sequent interpretable in \mathcal {C}. We say that \sigma is satisfied in M, denoted as M \models \sigma , if {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\varphi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} \leq {\mathopen {}\llbracket \Gamma .\psi \rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{M} in the preorder \mathsf {Sub}(M(\Gamma )).

fr:title.text: Identity morphisms in a regular category

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Identity morphisms in a regular category

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let \mathcal {C} be a regular category. f\colon A\to A is the identity morphism iff x\colon A|\top \vdash f(x) = x is satisfied in the internal language of \mathcal {C}.

Suppose that f is the identity morphism. Then by , {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} is \mathsf {id}_{A} \circ {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. But the equalizer with itself is the terminal object. Thus, \top \leq {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} in \mathsf {Sub}(A) as required.

Conversely, suppose that the terminal object of \mathsf {Sub}(A) (i.e., the identity morphism \mathsf {id}_{A}) factors through {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x) = x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Then it follows that \mathsf {id}_{A} equalizes {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}}. Since {\mathopen {}\llbracket x\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = \mathsf {id}_{A} and {\mathopen {}\llbracket f(x)\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = {\mathopen {}\llbracket f\rrbracket \mathclose {}}_{\mathcal {C}} = f, it follows that f = \mathsf {id}_{A}.

Let M be a \Sigma -structure in a category \mathcal {C}. Fix an axiomatization of a theory \mathscr {T} interpretable in \mathcal {C}. Then M is a model of \mathscr {T}, denoted as M \vDash \mathscr {T}, if every axiom of (the given axiomatization of) \mathscr {T} is satisfied.

The category \mathscr {T}\text {-}\mathsf {Mod}(\mathcal {C}) is the full subcategory of \Sigma \text {-}\mathsf {Str}(\mathcal {C}) spanned by the models of \mathscr {T}, and the category \mathscr {T}\text {-}\mathsf {Mod}(\mathcal {C})_{e} has the same objects as \mathscr {T}\text {-}\mathsf {Mod}(\mathcal {C}) but the morphisms are all elementary morphisms.
A sequent over a signature \Sigma is a formal expression of the form \Gamma | \varphi \vdash \psi , where \varphi and \psi are formulas and \Gamma is a context suitable for both \varphi and \psi .

Let \mathcal {C} be a category with finite products and \Sigma be a signature. The category of \Sigma -structures in \mathcal {C}, denoted as \Sigma \text {-}\mathsf {Str}(\mathcal {C}), consists of the following data:

html:tr.html:td:
A \Sigma -structure consists of the following data:
Each sort A in \Sigma is associated with an object MA in \mathcal {C}. This is extended to any finite string of sorts by the assignment M(A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}) \mapsto MA_{1} \times \cdots \times MA_{n}. The empty string is associated with the terminal object 1 of \mathcal {C}.
Each function symbol f\colon A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}\to B is associated with a morphism Mf\colon M(A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n})\to MB in \mathcal {C}.
Each relation symbol R \rightarrowtail A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n} is associated with a subobject of M(A_{1},\ldots ,A_{n}) in \mathcal {C}.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Composition and identities are defined componentwise from those in \mathcal {C}.
